Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Cloning of Estrogen Receptor (ER) in the Japanese Scallop and Expression Profiles of ER

The aim of this project was to extend an existing partial DNA sequence of the gene encoding estrogen receptor 2 in the Japanese scallop. The estrogen receptor is important because it plays a significant role in reproduction and fertility in many species of vertebrate. In invertebrates, it appears to play some role in reproduction, although the exact role it plays is unknown. Also, steroid hormones isolated from vertebrates that normally bind to estrogen receptors form other species do not bind to the marine invertebrate estrogen receptors. Learning more about the estrogen receptor in the scallop will hopefully give us more information about marine invertebrate reproduction, potentially allowing us to control the spawning and aquaculture of these important food sources. Also, the estrogen receptor of the marine invertebrate is a very interesting gene, as it appears to be constitutively active, i.e., constantly "on" in its normal state. An estrogen receptor that is constantly on is very different from the estrogen receptors found in mammals and other vertebrate species.

The estrogen receptor was a difficult gene to work on in the scallop, as previous graduate students have attempted to complete the gene sequence and have had limited success, even though other genes have been successfully sequenced in Professor Osada's laboratory.

I succeeded in extending a portion of the estrogen receptor 2 on the 3' end of the gene, using a technique called RACE (rapid amplification of cDNA ends) and amplifying this gene product using RNA extracted from gill tissue.

In addition to the new protocols and cloning expertise I gained while I was in Japan, I learned a great deal about Japanese culture while in Professor Osada's laboratory. I wish to continue my friendship with members of his laboratory for the rest of my life, and highly recommend this program to any graduate students who are interested in studying abroad. The EAPSI summer program was the opportunity of a lifetime.
